intro: Symphonia tanalensis var. parvicalyx, commonly known as the small-leaf symphonia, is a deciduous tree native to tropical regions of South America. It is characterized by its smooth, gray bark and elongated, elliptical leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers followed by woody, capsule-like fruits containing several seeds. It thrives in humid, well-drained soils and is often found in lowland rainforests. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
